Zulip discussion:
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.237404.20VCSP

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

-->

nodes.body:
> Does ` ofArity` already exist?

No, but [`Arity`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/ZFC/Basic.html#Arity) does, which would only need a tiny generalization to cover your case.

> > Does ` ofArity` already exist?
> 
> No, but [`Arity`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/ZFC/Basic.html#Arity) does, which would only need a tiny generalization to cover your case.

Does it mean I should replace the existing definition `Arity` by my definition on order to have only one?
Sure, but here "replace" is really just "add one more argument to"

> Some more smaller comments.
> 
> One last remark: this file currently only contains definitions. You have plans to actually prove things about these definitions, right?

Yes, but those theorems will require a lot more definitions that build on these definitions. Therefore, I would like to get these definitions merged first, as large PRs take forever to review.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  Build succeeded!

  The publicly hosted instance of bors-ng is deprecated and will go away soon.

  If you want to self-host your own instance, [instructions are here][instructions].
  For more help, visit [the forum].

  If you want to switch to GitHub's built-in merge queue, visit [their help page][gh].

  [instructions]: https://github.com/bors-ng/bors-ng#how-to-set-up-your-own-real-instance
  [the forum]: https://forum.bors.tech
  [gh]: https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/configuring-pull-request-merges/managing-a-merge-queue



  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6625786493/job/17997416809)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6625786493/job/17997416435)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6625786493/job/17997416007)
LGTM after `Deleteme` is deleted.
I think this looks mostly good. Can you already formulate something with the current definitions that you want to prove?

Some more smaller comments.

One last remark: this file currently only contains definitions. You have plans to actually prove things about these definitions, right?
LGTM after `Deleteme` is deleted.

I don't think this PR is meaningfully reviewable in its current form; a definition with no API isn't of any use, and you can't tell if a definition is the right one until you start defining/proving things in terms of it.

Thanks anyways for having a look!
Let's decide the `ofArity` vs `Arity` thing and then I'll make some API.
I strongly suspect the answer is going to be "you don't want `Arity` here anyway"...
What is your suspicion based on, please?
Arity removed.

```suggestion
  __ := Bool.linearOrder
```
You would save yourself a lot of work by dropping these!

Which is to say,
```suggestion
```

It works without them!!
How so?
I didn't know I could omit some parts of a typeclass.

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```
Very weird, but I have no idea how to debug this...

**[lint-bib]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion @Article{ cohen2012, author = {David A. Cohen and Martin C. Cooper and Páidí Creed and Peter G. Jeavons and Stanislav Živný}, title = {An Algebraic Theory of Complexity for Discrete Optimisation}, journal = {CoRR}, volume = {abs/1207.6692}, year = {2012}, url = {http://arxiv.org/abs/1207.6692}, eprinttype = {arXiv}, eprint = {1207.6692}, timestamp = {Mon, 03 Aug 2020 17:29:56 +0200}, biburl = {https://dblp.org/rec/journals/corr/abs-1207-6692.bib}, bibsource = {dblp computer science bibliography, https://dblp.org} ```

Do you need this structure at all? Shouldn't it be enough to give a cost function and a constraint to define an optimization problem (your `ValuedCspTerm`)? Prescribing a set of possible cost functions seems like an unnecessary overhead to me to just define an optimization problem (I'm thinking of linear/convex programming).

At the very least it might be a good idea to define constructors for `ValuedCspTerm` that only take as input the cost function and constraints.

There exists a rich theory that classifies VCSP depending on algebraic properties of the allowed cost functions.

Starting on the `ValuedCspTerm` level isn't interesting IMO.
Speaking in everyday mathematical language, one `ValuedCspTerm` represents either a function or a constraint. You need more of them to make the VCSP instance interesting.

Also not clear on the need for this if it's just a list of things already defined, and whether it should be named `ValuedCspInstance`. I suspect there is some naming convection in the literature that differs from the Mathlib meaning of instance.

That's not really a list of optimization problems. `ValuedCspInstance` is one optimization problem; it consists of terms that overlap in the variables referred from them. If you want to optimize a function given some constraints, you provide the function to be minimized as a `ValuedCspTerm` with rational values and the constraints as `ValuedCspTerm` with {0, infinity} values.

Note that I am not referring to the meaning of a typeclass instance (which would be a Lean terminology, not an optimization terminology).

For example, we want to minimize (1/x + 1/y) on { (x, y) | x > 0, y > 0, x + y = 2 }.
The domain will be positive rationals.
The template will contain (at least) the following two functions:
* a unary function that calculates the reciprocal
* a binary function that returns zero when the arguments sum up to 2 and infinity otherwise

The instance then consists of two terms that use the unary function and one term that uses the binary function.
The optimum solution is x = 1 = y, which we represent as `fun (_ : Fin 2) => (1 : ℚ)` in Lean.

I see. This is too foreign to me :(
I'm used to studying optimization theory in the convex programming context which takes a very different approach. I don't think I'll be able to provide any meaningful feedback here, sorry.
A general comment; where possible, `Type _` should be `Type*` throughout.
Will be `Type` instead.
Or is it something that the comment by @fpvandoorn does not apply to?
Actually `n1aryOfUnary` and  `n2aryOfBinary` will be with `Type*`. Can all definitions about VCSP be in `Type` tho?

No, you should almost never use `Type` without a `*`. I fully agree with Eric here, you should use `Type*` by default.

The reason that `D : Type` in the structure is sort-of acceptable, is 
* It's a structure field, and adding a new universe there makes the structure depend on another universe, which is annoying
* It's almost always a finite indexing type, so should live in the bottom universe. It's still possible that using `Type` will come to bite us later.

But in short: use `Type*` everywhere else.
Ah, I get it. I will refector everything but `D` to `Type*` as @eric-wieser suggested.
are none of these imports transitively imported by other imports?
I will filter them out.
camelCase (also below)
Since this is usually a finite type, i think it's fine to say this must live in the bottom type universe. Can you add a comment in the docstring (so that it's clear that it's intentional).

Possible different design decision: have an indexing type `α`, and two functions `a : α → ℕ` and `∀ i, (Fin (a i) → D) → C`. Not sure if that is better though.
But then the first 3 fields of `ValuedCspTerm` can just be `x : α`.
I'll think about it!
I don't think it would be better.
camelCase, probably rename to `ValuedCspTerm.ofUnary` (also below)

```suggestion
  (I.map (·.evalSolution x)).sum
```
(not important, of course)
Why `List`? The order is important? If not, use `Finset`. (sums over `Finset` have arguably a better API)
Did you mean `Multiset` please?
If you care about the duplication, then multiset is better yes.

The objective is to minimize a sum of terms. It may happen that two terms (among those that are summed) are equal. I'm not saying it is particularly useful to have duplicates, but it would be weird for the definition to forbid it (and it would probably create many issues later on).
Do you think `Multiset` is easier to work with than `List`? I probably don't care about ordering the terms in the objective function.

```suggestion
  positivity
```
(needs `import Mathlib.Tactic.Positivity`)
What does this comment mean?
It means that, in this example (which is here only temporarily and won't be added to mathlib), `True` and `False` are swapped out of convenience.

I don't see the swap. Either way, this instance is bad because mathlib already defines `b1 + b2` as `b1 ^^^ b2`, but you define it with `||` instead.

( I realize it's just here for your example, but I think this makes it a bad example too)
I should have defined an instance that makes `True ≤ False` and so on.

If there is already an instance that treats plus as xor, it wouldn't be a linear order, right?
My code reuses `Bool.linearOrder` tho.
This could maybe stick around in the `test` folder.
It wasn't my plan, but it could be done.
I think it's worth keeping as an example

The thing is that the definitions are close to being mergeable, but the examples haven't been polished much.

Therefore I suggest we do this PR without examples and I will add examples as a subsequent PR that can be review simultaneously with [more theory that builds on top of this PR].

```suggestion
structure ValuedCspTemplate.Term (Γ : ValuedCspTemplate D C) (ι : Type*) where
```
All of my renamings are suggestions, feel free to not apply them if you want. In this case, this allows you to write `Γ.Term`.
You didn't like my previous suggestion of `ValuedCspTerm.ofUnary`?
I don't like `ValuedCspTerm.something` if there is no `ValuedCspTerm` to speak of.
`ValuedCspTemplate.Instance`?

```suggestion
def ValuedCspInstance.OptimalSolution {Γ : ValuedCspTemplate D C} {ι : Type*}
```
`Optimum` is usually used as a noun.

I thought that `Optimum` is stronger than `Optimal`, i.e., `Optimum` is better than everything, `Optimal` can be incomparable with some elements (you can have several nonidentical optimal solutions). Did I get the terminology wrong?
I'm not sure, it's not important though.

These definitions are a bit sad that they're needed. We try to avoid such definitions, because if you have them, then eventually you need to prove a lot of little lemmas about them.
What do you think about inlining these definitions?

If we decide to keep them, they need to be moved to `Data.Fin.Tuple` or something.
I think https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/7773/files will solve this issue.
`Function.OfArity.uncurry` by @eric-wieser will replace these two definitions.
I think you might need the universe polymorphism for it to work as a drop-in replacement

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion import Mathlib.Combinatorics.Optimization.Deleteme import Mathlib.Combinatorics.Optimization.ValuedCSP ```
Very nice! Didn't know this notation existed!
`{x,y,z}` works for everything that has `Singleton` and `Insert`, so `Set`, `Finset`, `Multiset`, etc.

```suggestion
def ValuedCsp.Instance (Γ : ValuedCsp D C) (ι : Type*) : Type _ :=
```
(note this is one of the places where `Type _` is ok.

```suggestion
def ValuedCsp.Instance.IsOptimumSolution {Γ : ValuedCsp D C} {ι : Type*}
```
seems a little clearer that this doesn't carry data.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - General valued constraint satisfaction problem defined
